replies.author: @arielleblueford-davis544
replies.text:
For me it has been *much* more disheartening to realize that I am the minority, I'm not "pretending" or "disavowing" things that don't reflect kindness/decency or what have you, it's that I *GENUINELY* get a little sick watching things that are bigoted, rapey, or whatever. I have loved certain songs my ENTIRE life, and now, hearing Diddy's voice on them makes me feel literally ill. 

And when I speak up about that, people have insinuated that I am "moralizing" and that "you know you still like it, you just feel like you shouldn't" - and while I'd never say DELETE those songs completely, or other media bc of the reasons stated in the video....

I genuinely, *TRULY* had no idea how people are still deriving genuine enjoyment from those types of things while believing they "care" about rape, or dv victims. Just like they thought I was lying about secretly still being into media that depicts certain things and people as desirable, I, on the other hand, thought *those people* were lying about saying they think rape and coercion is wrong, and abhorrent, but still getting their chuckles easily while watching How I Met Your Mother, for example. I literally *can't overlook it, because I CANNOT find raping and coercing women funny*, bc that's not funny to me. Clearly it is to other people. I cannot bop my head to songs where there are lines clearly about underage kids and violence towards women, because I genuinely cannot find them fun. Bc that's not *fun* to me. One thing cancels out the other.

And yes, I have a spectrum- so I'm able to suspend disbelief with Powerpuff Girls and other things, sometimes, but I still can only get but so far into Sex and the City- EVEN THO I enjoyed it originally as a lil kid, *because* I don't find their casual racism, bigotry and nonsense fun. It takes me out of the "fun", even though, clearly it doesn't for plenty of other people. Some shows and things are fun enough for me to ignore the fly in the ointment, but I never am able to pretend the fly isn't there, or not be disgusted there's a fly in the first place.

And I wish there was a phrase for people like me, who aren't "practicing virtue mirroring" or purposefully trying to browbeat others. I was and continue to be *GENUINELY* shocked and bummed that I am apparently the weird one.

replies.author: @noxteryn
replies.text:
@ToastyT-l9k 
It's not about keeping your mouth shut. It's about opening yourself up to engage intellectually with any topic. There is literally nothing in this world that is not worthy of thought, because thinking elevates yourself, not the thing. So, it doesn't matter whether something is objectively "deep" enough to warrant discussion; what matters is whether or not you are willing to look for meaning. The act of analysis is about you, not about the thing.

replies.author: @davidmarshal8286
replies.text:
It‚Äôs human nature‚Äîonce we point out a ‚Äúproblem‚Äù in media, we can‚Äôt help but seek a solution.
But when criticism always frames the problem as some harmful social context, the solution often becomes simply to shame, reject, or erase the work itself.
This is why people get defensive or hostile; but more importantly, I don‚Äôt think this is what real criticism should be.
Good criticism should open us up, not close us off.
When critique narrows our perspective‚Äîmaking us hesitant, fearful, less able to engage with complexity and contradiction‚Äîit fails its purpose.
At that point, we‚Äôre not expanding our understanding or empathy, but only building smaller rooms in which to hide from the messiness of art and life.

replies.author: @gabrielleduplessis7388
replies.text:
@LilShopofAli yeah. I also don‚Äôt like how more viewers only watch movies and shows from a surface level. 

People look at me like I am insane when I overanalyze why I love or hate a show. It is hard finding people in the real world who want to overanalyze media like I do. That is how we engage with it. That is how we relate to characters.  

The more I think about it, overanalyzing is not that. It is basic media literacy. Also, saying it is not that deep or that we shouldn‚Äôt over analyze everything disrespects the time and effort everyone put into the project. 

For example, XO Kitty is seen as bad by viewers who only see it from a surface level, but on rewatches and talking about it with XO Kitty fans and analyzers, so much time, thought, effort, symbolism, foreshadowing, etc. is put into it. People just need to care enough to see that. 

I am always amazed at how much styling and costuming can tell a story, even contemporary clothing. But stuff like this gets missed when we only watch something at a surface level. 

Also, analyzing and deconstructing is what we learned in school, especially in English classes. 

Also, I feel seeing movies at a surface level is how we fall into bad propaganda. Sometimes, it is that deep.  

It‚Äôs not that deep shouldn‚Äôt be the answer to everything.

replies.author: @palyername
replies.text:
@gothgammy666 I don't think it should be controversial to say something has to be a conspiracy or propaganda to have influence on people, especially impressionable children. How I Met Your Mother isn't a conspiracy or propaganda, either - it just normalized and perpetuated toxic views on women that were socially acceptable at the time (and unfortunately still are). I don't think the argument being made here is that PPG is deliberate, conspiratorial propaganda meant to indoctrinate children into believing cops are good and people committing crimes are evil, but instead that regardless of intent, it does have the effect of teaching children that law enforcement is always in the right and should be able to achieve their goals by any means necessary. The assumption that this is true makes it easy to write a good vs evil narrative easily understood by children, and I can see the appeal of being able to rely on that on the part of the showrunners, but it does have the side effect of teaching children that cops are always good and those who have committed crimes are always deserving of violence.

"Copaganda" in general does tend to mean media that goes out of its way to glorify and exonerate cops on purpose, but media that rides the coattails of deliberate propaganda by relying on the same worldview has a similar effect, so they are often grouped together; I think the most important thing is interrogating the assumption that the police are always justified and always have good intentions, and I think PPG was a perfectly valid example of that. This also definitely isn't the first time I've heard someone point to PPG as easily-missed copaganda - it portrays extrajudicial violence on the behalf of the government as brave, honorable, and heroic. Yes, it is *usually* (but notably, not always) after we've seen the villain doing something blatantly harmful and evil because they are a literal cartoon villain, but the protagonists don't just drive the villain off to protect the civilians they're hurting - they throw the villain in jail, explicitly on the mayor's behalf, and that imagery and framing sends a message about law enforcement that isn't necessary to the premise of 3 kindergarteners with superpowers born in a lab saving the day.

replies.author: @serebii666
replies.text: @thompsonnoel Alan Moore did not say that. He said "The superhero dream Is essentially fascism", which has little to do with the subject matter, but everything to do with the audience that consumes the media. So it is not the superheroes themselves that are fascist, but rather that having a large audience/fan base of adults attracted to superhero stories puts a society at risk of fascism - due to the parallels between that desire and wish for some singular being or entity that is better/stronger/smarter/wiser/etc that regular humanity would come along and solve all our problems for us while we stand by passively in the background waiting to be saved being fundamentally the same instinct that leads populations to end up supporting authoritarian fascist regimes, as the underlying premise of fascism and the way it sells itself to its society also relies on that exact sell. Superheroes themselves are Deus ex machina, anthropomorphic narrative devices. They are the modern era equivalent of the supernatural Gods of Mythology and folk entities, whose stories now reflect their existence as what we now consider vigilantes beyond the order of supposedly Enlightened egalitarian, a social innovation that didn't exist back in the era of Mythology. Neither vigilantes, like the Gods, Titans and spirits of yore are as a rule fascists.

One of the series of books I‚Äôm writing right now actually goes into this.  1930‚Äôs, Grace falls in love with one man in the mob, and something she does contend with is having feelings for a man she knows kills people, and how she‚Äôll try to either justify it or keep herself in the dark.  When she‚Äôs abducted and being forced to marry another mob boss, despite the bad shit he does, she sees who he could have been if he‚Äôd made other choices.  One of her best friends, the daughter of a corrupt politician, is with a clean-cut man (he‚Äôs my favorite), who is also a friend of Grace‚Äôs, and that man becomes loose friends with the one Grace ends up with, but you can tell there is a wall still, due to the crime element.

I have a pet peeve about how these things are always entirely overlooked and never addressed.  So the stuff I write does address it all.  You see their nice sides, but their bad sides are still there and aren‚Äôt handwaved away.

We have to look past the lies and manipulations of the narrator who tries to present Lolita as this overly sexualized girl who has seduced him but he constantly slips up and reveals the pain and suffering that Lolita goes through. replies.author: @Jean-SethBeauchene
replies.text:
One of my favorite characters is deeply unlikable. Richard Papen from The Secret History is a pathological liar as a result of horrific insecurity due to growing up lower class, internalizing classicism and being emotionally and psychologically abused by his father. It is a haunting portrait of how abuse and classicism can destroy someone. He gets into a good school. He gets everything he wanted. He's not happy because he loathes himself for not being rich and perfect and he can't emotionally connect to anyone because his pathological lying, originally developed to appease his abusive father, has put up walls between him and everyone else. I don't like him. But it really opened my eyes to how classicism can be internalized and be damaging to someone psychologically. And it really made me rethink my kneejerk instincts to dislike liars, as you don't know what they're going through.

And then tumblr and Tiktok hate the book because Richard is unlikeable. Apparently they never thought to ask how he got this way or why the author made him like this. (Hint: it's because you're not supposed to root for his classist ambitions and ideology IT IS RUINING HIS LIFE.) The book is used in courses on classism and people don't get it, not because it's hard, but because they get as far as him lying to escape his abusive dad and go "wow he lied he's so unlikeable".

replies.author: @Criicketprime
replies.text:
@athousandandonenights11 I think that‚Äôs fair, but there‚Äôs also true merit to being more direct about how you‚Äôre supposed to interpret morally reprehensible characters in an age with poor media literacy (that has also just come off a different age of the super common trope of Morally Reprehensible Guy Saves Day, Is Awesome, Therefore Is Redeemed). 

The major driver of them making it clearer was when Harvey Weinstein said he liked Bojack and that Bojack felt relatable. Already there were many that, like with Rick Sanchez, felt vindicated in seeing someone who struggled in a dark but genuine way, but ultimately caused serious harm to everyone that surrounded them with that same darkness. 

They were already underlining that Bojack was a bad guy from the get go and in the finale of S3, Todd serves as a mouthpiece for a more direct version of the messaging by stating that the problem IS Bojack and that Bojack can‚Äôt keep doing bad things then feeling bad about them as if that makes it better. He has to BE better. It‚Äôs really easy to miss that messaging when it‚Äôs done in a more subtle way through the narrative, especially when Bojack is genuinely a very witty, funny, relatable character and has some of the best lines in the show. Similar to the earlier portrayal of Rick Sanchez in Rick and Morty, where he‚Äôs shown to be an objectively bad guy but is still Very Awesome and Cool. It blurs the line in the overall narrative of this shitty character that you‚Äôre presenting as a bad person, but making story choices where the bad things the character does ends up working out for the better or worse, somehow saving the day even though they‚Äôve caused so much damage in other ways. 

It‚Äôs a really fine narrative line to toe between that often tips into glorifying/romanticizing and even when the writers of BH got very blatant, they still were able to drive home that people live in shades of gray that often aren‚Äôt totally morally good or bad, but just‚Ä¶ are. And that even if you‚Äôre the worst person in the world, it does not mean you cannot make meaningful changes for yourself, take responsibility, and heal‚Äî even if that means your life and relationships can never be what they were before. And that your actions have lasting consequences and you will have to face those consequences every day to work toward a better you.

replies.author: @concerninghobbits5536
replies.text:
@fromlissawithlovetrue I've seen so many jokes about Paw Patrol being a cop show.  Recently I've liked The Rookie but it does a good job of having relevant themes but not feeling too forced, and they at least try to be honest and current with their representation of GOOD cops.  But it's less making cops look good and more showing what a good cop SHOULD be like and they've had a lot of subplots with police brutality, profiling, corruption, etc.  I'm not sure how it would stand up to a proper analysis but it definitely tries to be more human and nuanced.  Plus it's just got a likeable cast and the scripts weave in a lot of humour.

But yeah a lot of cop shows have been and still are just very sanitised and Hollywood cliche feeling.  Mostly just good cops arresting bad guys and not much substance or depth.

replies.author: @MiraBoo
replies.text:
Oh, the two definitely go hand in hand. 

Too many people treat *basic vocabulary* like it‚Äôs highfalutin verbiage or advanced terminology. 

For instance, if I do not sufficiently dumb down my vocabulary, people will stop listening to what I‚Äôm actually saying and accuse me of being pretentious. It‚Äôs nuts. 

Such people cannot be expected to be media literate when they can‚Äôt even comprehend‚Äîor outright refuse to learn‚Äîthe most simple words and concepts. It‚Äôs shameful. 

But that‚Äôs what happens when public services, like education, are constantly and increasingly neglected: the populace becomes dumb and pliable.

replies.author: @englishandcompositionlearn6745
replies.text: I think it has more to do with how and why society reacts to "problematic" content and what that tells us about the political climate of the time. For example, in the 70's, shows like All in the Family, The Jeffersons, Sanford & Son, Good Times and many others all joked about race in ways that you could never get away with now. But these shows were important for opening the door to a dialogue that before then we'd never been permitted to have on TV. The fact that black characters could also be bigoted and racist (ala' George Jefferson and Fred Sanford) was, I think, an important milestone for entertainment at the time. They allowed us as an audience a way to step back and look at ourselves, and of course, much of the humor was reactionary (payback for all the years that blacks had been the butt of racist jokes and the humor), The way these shows handled themes of bigotry and racism was a necessary if somewhat bumpy bridge from the era where these things couldn't even be acknowledged at all to a time when we were obviously comfortable enough about race to joke about it. So while it's easy to cringe at the jokes now, the context of time and place is definitely important.

Insisting that entertainment be politically correct isn't just censorship; it's missing the entire point of why we have entertainment.

I mean, to be fair, it gets complicated at times.   There's a lot of old media that's meant to be provocative and unsettling, to raise a mirror to the problems of the time.  White Wolf loved to do this in their silly D&D-type games about vampires and werewolves; they wanted to attack things like racism, homophobia, and other forms of bigotry.   Vampire: the Masquerade was a lot of people's first exposure gender non-conforming people... Hell, it's partially responsible for me finding my own non-binary identity. 

At the same time, the most iconic gender non-conforming character in the setting is a vampire that leans heavily into the "vampires are sexual predators" trope and the popular right-wing rhetoric that all trans people are sexual predators, it isn't a great look.   But the intent was never to imply they were a monster because of their gender fluidity; rather they are a gender fluid person that just so happens to be a (literal, on account of being a vampire) monster.

author: @kilgore_trout_37
text:
When folks say ‚Äúit‚Äôs not that deep‚Äù- it IS. This is not a documentary, that‚Äôs an actor who‚Äôs performing lines written for them. Every word was selected and possibly agonized over, reviewed by a committee of other writers, signed off on by a show runner and a tv/movie studio. Camera positions, angles, filters  and lenses were selected to help to create mood and emphasize themes. Lighting was selected and adjusted. Actors were cast to be the correct delivery method of the message. Actors are trained to move with purpose- the blocking of the performance is decided in advance to coordinate all of these elements together. Did you notice that actor deliver their line and then check their nails? Did the camera linger? Is there a close up? These things are all choices and they‚Äôre somewhere in print because many people made choices. It‚Äôs 100% that deep, it is DEEPER. There are shoes selected to complete that outfit that got cropped out of the final. That makeup job was done a bit lighter today to make that character seem more soft. That camera angle was selected to make the perspective from below so that we the audience feel that person is powerful. Film and television and theater all have a language that they‚Äôre communicating in and YES we love it when the audience is engaged and picking up all of these nuances. 

TLDR it‚Äôs not a documentary! RIP the DVD extras director‚Äôs commentary. ‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§

replies.author: @vidmuncher
replies.text:
‚Äã@dolphinswilltakeover Yeah, there isn't any intentionality in the weather, it's found in how we interact with it, among other things - after all, "You can plan a pretty picnic but you can't predict the weather". No one plans an event for a day they know won't have amenable weather for said event if they can help it...

Speaking of "other things", the intentionality is also found in the choices we make about the the things we CAN control. We put colorful decorations in our personal and public spaces that are often themed in some way to our liking. We play music in our cars, our buildings, at different events or even just in our yards (something others hear as well). It may not be in our brains, for better and for worse, but video broadcasts are much closer to POV footage of an event than it isn't. And that's before we even get to more direct forms of communication like conversation.

Much like creatives make creative decisions about the sensory simulations we collectively call art, we all are making creative decisions about the world around us - the results of those decisions just happen to be more diegetic than the ones the artists are making....

author: @necordektox879
text:
My partner had a conversation like this with his mom recently. They all watched NCIS when he was growing up (my family did too), and once when my partner was arguing with her about cops not following the law, she said, "But Gibbs does that all the time and you think he's the good guy!" My partner had to sit her down and explain that the show is trying to create an interesting story, not make a good representation of how police work should function in real life.

They also watch Bones, and the 9/11 episode is so interesting as someone who was too young to remember that time. The Atheist "skeptic" character talks about how there's no evidence of WMDs in Iraq, and the rest of the characters shut him down and tell him he's being disrespectful, despite history proving him right. It's like a little snapshot of how people at that time felt and how we got to where we are.

author: @arih_rih
text: media is the perfect place for imperfect characters. Barney doesn‚Äôt exist, so you can acknowledge he‚Äôs a predator and still like him. ‚Äúvirtue mirroring‚Äù is a great term for this, cuz it gets to the heart of how people struggle on such a superficial level to reconcile liking a character but not agreeing with everything they do. media both is and isn‚Äôt a mirror. it can reveal the norms of the times and you can choose how you engage with that. you can even like bad things in a safe way. another great Olurinatti joint

replies.author: @YouAreStillNotablaze
@arih_rih
replies.text:
@YouAreStillNotablaze yeah absolutely, that‚Äôs the point i was agreeing with, which is Olayemi‚Äôs argument in the video. Barney was portrayed as a charming funny guy. his constant predatory behavior was not actually criticized within the show. or much outside of the show, at that time. that‚Äôs why we look back and cringe. it was way more common at the time, both in media and in real life, to normalize and glorify predatory behavior. but looking back we can and should criticize it. you can also still like his character or the show without that reflecting directly on your own values.

that‚Äôs the whole point of the term Olayemi has coined here ‚Äúvirtue mirorring.‚Äù generally we shouldn‚Äôt look to shows and movies to portray back to us our exact values and how we want the world to work, those things have their value and place (like with abolition and imagining a better world, that‚Äôs super important). but like we gotta operate on multiple levels and engage in media analysis. under current power structures, a lot of media is still gonna be bad and try to normalize bad things, like the pervasive copaganda landscape we have now (and have had for a while). you can enjoy law and order svu while also recognizing it for what it is, copaganda and straight up lies. it doesn‚Äôt make us bad for liking shows that uncritically portray bad norms, it‚Äôs when we agree with and just absorb those things and make excuses for them, without taking a step back and thinking about what‚Äôs happening and how we have agency, that‚Äôs when it‚Äôs a big issue. sorry i‚Äôm a rambler, so this is probably incoherent but i hope my reply helped a bit.

text:
I really appreciated your take in this video. I think your definition of Virtue Mirroring was really eye opening, especially using it to describe the way many people talk about HP these days. I personally am still not really into re-reading the series even though I still own the books, but that's multi-faceted. In growing and reading other series, I just found myself with less of an interest in it and the way it actually engages with its world and world building. It ultimately became clear to me that I like the universe *around* HP (fandom/fanfiction/analysis videos/A very Potter Musical) more than I cared for the original books.
The response to the series You stressed me the math out. I do have to wonder how people would have responded if he was less conventionally attractive for sure, and it is interesting to see how the actor responded to it all.

Lucifer satirizes cop shows. Detective Chloe Decker solves complex criminal cases with relative ease‚Äîprocedure & the law be damned‚Äîbecause she has the assistance of the literal Devil. Lucifer‚Äôs characters work in law enforcement, but the show isn‚Äôt really about cops.

author: @walliam5506
text: This video is so intensely satisfying to me because I swear every time I see someone call out something for being problematic, there‚Äôs at least 20 people burying their head in the sand and insisting it isn‚Äôt, and 20 more acting like they‚Äôre a pure of heart saint for never being interested in it. Like y‚Äôall, you can like problematic shit! I don‚Äôt care! That thing you love can be amazing and life changing, and also a hot mess, it happens! Nothing is purely ‚Äúflawless‚Äù or ‚Äúunproblematic‚Äù and IMO it doesn‚Äôt need to be, and treating media as either Purely Good or Purely Evil is a generalization steeped in anti-intellectualism that misses the point. I am 110% stealing ‚ÄúVirtue Mirroring‚Äù as a phrase to describe exactly this issue, and this video was an amazing watch.

author: @teetrea2688

I used to be like that, no critical analysis. And it was because asking questions and further analysis was often punished, especially in my religious upbringing. I was quite literally taught to question nothing and accept confusion, not to point out connections. 

This was compounded by an actual learning disability. I might be slower to reach my conclusion or express it in words, but I'm always aware that we should be thinking critically about what we consume.

author: @phaIIicaIIyimpaired
text:
Virtue mirroring is genuinely such a great term to describe this phenomenon! 

It's so exhausting to navigate creative fandom spaces nowadays, because people will massively judge you for liking evil or morally grey characters. And the most vocal people attacking other fans over this and projecting moral degeneracy onto them for liking "the bad guy" will themselves bend over backwards to excuse the evil actions of objectively awful characters if *they* happen to like them. Just a total lack of introspection.

author: @novataco5412

Of course that doesn‚Äôt mean that problematic things are good or don‚Äôt matter, or that future generations will be ‚Äúright‚Äù to regard our media in such way. But it is a fundamental reality of human cultural expression.

author: @oboestavs
text: Virtue mirroring is such a succinct term for the way I was taught to consume media growing up Mormon. Media had to adhere to all the same strict rules we did, and we were expected to turn it off and in some cases, destroy our "immoral" CDs and DVDs for things as minor as swearing (I shit you not; I heard so many stories of teenagers being held up as "truly changed by the Atonement" when they would take baseball bats to their rap albums üôÑ no racial implications there either üòë). So it's bothered me for quite some time how people are engaging with media out here in the secular world in the same regressive ways I was taught to in the high-demand religion I left. I didn't know how to articulate it for so long, so thank you for how you've done it!

author: @dancing_fig
text:
@42:00 - OMG, YES! Shows that incorporate consequences for their characters' actions are SO valuable and enjoyable! But the shows that endlessly let their protagonists off the hook are just fucking exhausting. It's like seeing a parent who constantly indulges their toddler and who never holds a boundary

And maybe it's the former childcare worker in me, maybe it's my autism, or maybe it's just me, but dear GODS is it soothing to see narratives where there's both cause and effect. I get enough nihilism in reality; I want there to be some element of causality and follow-through in my fiction

replies.author: @alpacafish1269
replies.text:
The parent to child analogy you gave is spot on! That‚Äôs exactly how i feel too when engaging in media like that. I just prefer when characters have consequences to their actions (makes em more relatable in that sense) rather than leaving them to be cause it‚Äôs even more interesting to see the potential reaction/after affect that character would have to those consequences. (Whether that reaction is positive or negative)
One note characters are just boring.

replies.author: @dancing_fig
replies.text:
@alpacafish1269 Yes! Someone once described it to me as the idea that it's way more interesting to give people/characters choices, and to have that drive the plot, compared to laying out the plot itself and just moving your characters through it. 

But if those choices never have any *effect* on the characters' lives, then it's pointless; you're just doing the pre-planned plot option after a fake-out of some character development

text:
I think there was a massive shift in both the importance of rationalizing the mass media someone consumes, and to a lesser extent, learning your blind spots or misunderstandings. It was the proliferation of cable TV, and now with streaming sites where you can curate your own TV channel... When you only had less than 10 channels on TV, a half dozen radio stations to choose from, etc. you dont have the agency available today. A bit like how airlines used to put a movie on a projector for everyone to watch... And now we get to judge the people around you on their choice of TV show on their personal entertainment screen. 

I truly enjoyed every second of the video. Thsnk you so much for the work and perspective you put into this. A lot of these ideas have been bouncing around my head for a LONG time. Like when the sunburned, goatee, wrap around sunglasses internet got real unglued about their sports being invaded by discussions or statements they didnt like (about paw patrol). 

And regarding JK Growling, the funny circle harry potter fanfic has gone through is hilarious. Its absolutely breaking copywrite law, or does when its monetized. Idk, not a lawyer. But either way, the best way to continue enjoying old media from trash people... Go find (or write) the most disrespectful, biting, blatantly extra fanfic, and go support that writer instead. Sometimes we gotta engage with stuff that makes us sad... So when youre on the nerflix or youtube homepage... intentionally, and knowingly queue up stuff that makes you feel good, or hopeful idk.

author: @elijahclaude3413
text:
Love this video!! 

Things that really served me well is to see how I can make the best of the media by asking:
1) What do I want from this media? - Sometimes I just wanna watch things blow up, sometimes I want something more cerebral, etc
2) What is this media saying? - Understanding what the creators meant to communicate allows me to better understand those people and my own media literacy
3) What media can I consume that will support people/politics I like and/or improve my own understanding? - This is the biggest thing I do to make sure I'm not just passively consuming stuff, but actively finding good media too. I feel like far too many people don't do enough to actually find and support good media and just complain about the mainstream media ('hiphop is dead', or 'AAA games suck' or 'TV is trash' etc) putting forth no effort to find all the amazing indie artists doing amazing stuff.

replies.author: @UhOhJacquinette
replies.text:
@noneofyourbusiness4616 I believe that‚Äôs the same point you made in the first post correct? 

And the short answer would be yes . I can absolutely see a Joe Jackson keeping his son to live in Gary Indiana in the 70s and 80s away from that culture or having people who live on the other side of the tracks‚Äù giving Michael Jackson this exact speech and then him using his musical to create a piece that resonates with cultures and generations in the future. And the Curtis mayfield point kinda proves what *I‚Äôm* saying more than it does for you‚Ä¶ he saw a beautiful Romani woman in a film and then wrote a song about falling in love with her at 12‚Ä¶ kinda checks out. 

.

author: @devinodonnell
text: Anyone that says "you're overthinking it" is someone that is simply telling you that they either cannot, or will not, devote the time and mental/emotional discomfort necessary, to fully engage with a narrative in a meaningful way. replies.author: @lahlybird895
replies.text:
That is not inherently always true 
I think just like with many other things there is an appropriate balance between not over correcting and falling to either extremes which are both bad 

Because there is such a thing as over analysis there are people who do in fact overthink it and take tiny things a little too far and read entirely different narratives that were never there and were never meant to be there 
 Add a small example a character being disliked in a narrative does not actually mean that the author dislikes every single person in the world who can relate to that character. 
Creating any amount of especially fictional media involves trying to balance your message with your character specific story and sometimes characters make choices because it fits their character not because it fits the overall agenda of the story being pushed. 
Some media can have unintentional or bad messages in it that the author wasn't aware of but it's also possible for people to force and read bad at messages and dramatic interpretations on to things that were not actually carrying those messages or or themes in them at all 
like how people insist on reading anti-feminist messages out of the Disney princesses even if reading those messages involves ignoring the actual plot story and characters just to push that idea that there is inherent problems that aren't actually there if you pay attention to those details. 
Is there are times when a story is just a story and part of being good at media analysis is being able to determine when that's the case. It's being aware that media impacts the world around us and therefore knowing how to engage with it and when to know whether it's impacting or whether you're taking it personally in a way that specific to you that may not actually affect other people. 
Part of not falling into what did she call it moral mirroring is being able to accept and understand that these characters are fictional and that it is okay to like them even if there are bad messages with them and part of that also includes not being overly attached to them as taking it personally whenever anything bad is said about them or acting like they are real or specific reflections of you

My partner and I are in our mid-late 40s. We constantly cringe at old shows, movies, music, etc.  A common phrase lately in our house has been taken from Michael Che, "It was the 90s ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èü§∑üèæ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è!"

By no means is this us being casually flippant. It's tongue in cheek. It's our way of acknowledging our OWN previous ignorance growing up in the 80s-2020s. It's coping. We do, however, move on to discuss WHY those things are wrong and how we feel about them now.

Maybe this makes us a-holes. I'm sorry if that's the take away. I think just having that little laugh between us really opens dialogue in our home for serious discussions.

author: @robotdjuret
text:
Someone linked to this on Bluesky and I just want to give this video, and particularly this distinction of virtue mirroring from ethical consumption, etc., an utterly unironic chef's kiss. You put into words something that has been driving me crazy as I've been forced into making policy decisions for a staff of like 35 people around what kind of stuff not to cover on my music review 'blog,' and why there's a distinction between electing not to give something publicity and liking it, for example. This is also the root of guilty pleasures discourse. "Like, I know this makes me bad for liking it, but..." Saying that is virtue signaling, but the fact that it's even occurring to a person is already suggesting that a lot of work has been going on internally to reconcile that this stupid reality TV show or liking the NFL despite concussions or loving reggaeton despite bad gender politics is "problematic" and therefore needs to be explained away in order to match someone's sense of self. Analysis kind of requires us to set that aside and to differentiate between these different ways that we relate to media.

I want to go back and read some sociology of identity to see how and if they're dealing with this. But  I literally just had to stop in and comment, because what a really useful and meaningful distinction. Thanks!

replies.author: @alfonsstekebrugge8049
replies.text: @sabrinabrainiacbri Having read plenty of video game analysis in academics, there's a problem with students trying to employ one frame and then just reach for the depths. It's a faulty way to go about it. Elden Ring is the same. It doesn't work employing a single frame. You'd need one for the world, one for the character and one for the player who plays the character. All frames develop throughout the game, but not in unison. I recommend listening to what Noah Caldwell-Gervais has to say on the topic, he tends to give an impressionistic take on any game he plays, I don't recall what he said about Elden Ring but his output is consistently valuable. Be aware that academic analysis has historically had a problem assuming full immersion, which isn't a valid assumption.
